jyoshu

http://www.latimes.com/news/opinion/commentary/la-oe-stein24jan24,0,4137172.column?coll=la-news-comment-opinions
 "I DON'T SUPPORT our troops. This is a particularly difficult opinion to have, especially if you are the kind of person who likes to put bumper stickers on his car. Supporting the troops is a position that even Calvin is unwilling to urinate on.
 
 But I'm not for the war. And being against the war and saying you support the troops is one of the wussiest positions the pacifists have ever taken"
 You know, I'm going to actually commend this columnist; not because of his position on the war, but because for ONCE someone on the anti-war side is being honest about what that position means and that opposition to the war AND support of the troops can't go hand-in-hand. For all this time anti-war people have been trying so hard to come across as being troop-friendly so they can try and not tick off most of the country. Anti-war sentiment can't be separated from being anti-troop if one is going to be consistent. It's why the Vietnam vets who returned were spat upon and mistreated. At least the anti-Vietnam war movement was less hypocritical. Doesn't make mistreating or not supporting our troops right, but I have to give this guy an "A" for consistency.

jitobear

http://www.latimes.com/news/opinion/commentary/la-oe-stein24jan24,0,4137172.column?coll=la-news-comment-opinions
 "I DON'T SUPPORT our troops. This is a particularly difficult opinion to have, especially if you are the kind of person who likes to put bumper stickers on his car. Supporting the troops is a position that even Calvin is unwilling to urinate on.
 
 But I'm not for the war. And being against the war and saying you support the troops is one of the wussiest positions the pacifists have ever taken"
 You know, I'm going to actually commend this columnist; not because of his position on the war, but because for ONCE someone on the anti-war side is being honest about what that position means and that opposition to the war AND support of the troops can't go hand-in-hand. For all this time anti-war people have been trying so hard to come across as being troop-friendly so they can try and not tick off most of the country. Anti-war sentiment can't be separated from being anti-troop if one is going to be consistent. It's why the Vietnam vets who returned were spat upon and mistreated. At least the anti-Vietnam war movement was less hypocritical. Doesn't make mistreating or not supporting our troops right, but I have to give this guy an "A" for consistency.

 
 Hogwash.
 
 One of the reasons I don't support the war is because I am sick of soldiers dieing, getting hurt, not seeing their families for over year becuase monkey man can't get it together. I certainly don't support their mission.
 
 And for the record I don't think we should pull out now. Too little too late. We need to clean up after ourselves.
Kronus

You know, I'm going to actually commend this columnist; not because of his position on the war, but because for ONCE someone on the anti-war side is being honest about what that position means and that opposition to the war AND support of the troops can't go hand-in-hand. 

 
 You missed the point of the article. He is anti-war and pro-troop. His point was that too many people, like you, think such a distinction is impossible. These people equate pro-troop with pro-war, and so get the idea that there's more support for the was than there really is. In order to prevent this, and thus bring a quicker end to the war, he's advocating toning down the pro-troop rhetoric. 
 
 "Blindly lending support to our soldiers, I fear, will keep them overseas longer by giving soft acquiescence to the hawks who sent them there - and who might one day want to send them somewhere else. Trust me, a guy who thought 50.7% was a mandate isn't going to pick up on the subtleties of a parade for just service in an unjust war."
sanguinekane

I dont understand people who are for the war on Iraq, and yet call themselves pro-soldier. On one hand, they say they support the men, women and others in uniform, and then with the other they sign documents sending them to their deaths in a far away land, ensuring a tour of constant hell and paranoi that leaves even the survivors with a definite change for the worse. I wish the pro-war side would be consistent and come out and say they hate the armed forces.
jyoshu

You missed the point of the article. He is anti-war and pro-troop. His point was that too many people, like you, think such a distinction is impossible. These people equate pro-troop with pro-war, and so get the idea that there's more support for the was than there really is. In order to prevent this, and thus bring a quicker end to the war, he's advocating toning down the pro-troop rhetoric. 

 
 No, he made it clear that he is saying one doesn't have to claim to support the troops just because he opposes the war. I just thought it was refreshing to see someone on your side not give the usual damage-control inconsistent rhetoric of "I oppose the war, but support the troops all the way!"
Kronus

No, he made it clear that he is saying one doesn't have to claim to support the troops just because he opposes the war. I just thought it was refreshing to see someone on your side not give the usual damage-control inconsistent rhetoric of "I oppose the war, but support the troops all the way!"

 
 Of course one doesn't have to support the troops to oppose the war, but that doesn't mean that you can't. Nothing in the article says otherwise. The author very clearly supports the troops, wishing them armor and medical care. He just doesn't want hawks to look at people's support for the troops and think that it means they support the war. Because some people, as you have so ably demonstrated, can't understand that the one doesn't imply the other, that they are in fact to distinct things.
Truthsayer

I suppose somebody needs to define the term "support our troops." Then we need to define the term "support the Iraqi war." Then we have to determine if we can do one without the other.
 
 I do not support Bush's war. But it is my sincerest desire that our troops are safe and are able to soon return home to their wives, husbands, children and family.
 
 If supporting our troops means having no objection to sending them off to some foreign soil to saturate it with American blood, for an unworthy cause, well....with friends like that, who needs enemies?
simone

I dont understand people who are for the war on Iraq, and yet call themselves pro-soldier. On one hand, they say they support the men, women and others in uniform, and then with the other they sign documents sending them to their deaths in a far away land, ensuring a tour of constant hell and paranoi that leaves even the survivors with a definite change for the worse. I wish the pro-war side would be consistent and come out and say they hate the armed forces.
You find it difficult to understand complex matters, don't you.
jyoshu

Because some people, as you have so ably demonstrated, can't understand that the one doesn't imply the other, that they are in fact to distinct things.

 
 That's the very thing I'm talking about on the anti-war side. When anti-war people claim to be anti-war but protroops. They don't get the distinction
daewoo

That's the very thing I'm talking about on the anti-war side. When anti-war people claim to be anti-war but protroops. They don't get the distinction

 
 Obviously they do. Otherwise they could not be anti war but pro troops. It is people lik eyou who fail to recognize the distinction.
 
 For example, I used to be anti war but indifferent to the troops. I considered the war to be a bad thing and the troops to simply be disposable employees fulfilling the funtion for which they were hired.
 
 Now I am ant war and anti troops. After reading accounts of some of our Iraqi "battles", tactical briefings, and speaking with command level officers that I know that have been to Iraq and are now back, I sincerely hope that the majority of our soldiers are killed, and the majority of the survivors should be tried for war crimes and either imprisoned for life or executed.
 
 Some people feel as I do about the war, but still feel that the troops are doing their best in a bad situation and as such should be respected.
 
 See the difference?
jyoshu

Obviously they do. Otherwise they could not be anti war but pro troops. 

 
 They aren't. They just think they are. That's the point.
 
 
Now I am anti war and anti troops.

 
 Then I commend you too for consistency and being honest; at least you aren't trying to kid yourself
Bassman
Looks like the anti-war peaceniks have started to show their true colors. They want America to lose at all costs. They think that the root to all of the world's problems is America.
sanguinekane

You find it difficult to understand complex matters, don't you.

 
 Not being serious. ;)
daewoo

They aren'tThen I commend you too for consistency and being honest; at least you aren't trying to kid yourself

 
 
 
 I wasn't trying to kid myself before when I supported the troops but not the war. The two are seperate entities.
Liminus

This is a very strange argument that seems to hinge on the use of the word 'support', or the phrase 'pro-troops'.
 I actually don't understand how it is possible to be either 'pro' or 'anti' troops in the same way that one can be pro-war or anti-war. These viewpoints are based on whether one thinks we have good reasons for the war, or that the war is a horrible mistake.
 However, the war is not just the troops, and the troops are not the war. The troops are human beings just like the rest of us, even though a small number seem to have become somewhat inhuman over recent years.
 I have complex feelings about the soldiers in Iraq, British, American or otherwise. I do not support the war, I believe it to be an ideological error on the part of politicians. I feel compassion for the troops out there, I do not want any of them to die, and now that we've gone ahead and done it I want them to do their jobs as effectively and safely as they can; I believe a total sudden pullout would be as disastrous as any worst case occupation scenario.
 I feel that the soldiers we have sent to Iraq are the victims of the politicians' and terrorists' wars just as much as the civilians who have died around the world in the last few years. I imagine that some soldiers have performed some heroic deeds, but some have made terrible mistakes, and grouping them all together as 'the troops' and demanding that people either be 'pro' or 'anti' doesn't make any sense to me, literally as well as emotionally.
 
 All I can say is that in the narrow, black-and-white spectrum of views exhibited by most of this forum on this particular issue, I would have to say I support the troops, but only insofar as I support most human beings who are not in direct control of their lives, members of the military and civilians embroiled in conflict being foremost among this category. 
 However I do not believe in the ideology behind the war, and do not believe our leaders' rhetoric concerning the war.
 I do not see how it can be misunderstood that these two views are irreconcilable.
Kronus

They aren't. They just think they are. That's the point.
 
 

 
 I think our troops are, for the most part, doing their duty as best they can in a horrible situation. I wish them the best and would like them home soon and safely. I'm pro-troops.
 
 I think the Iraq war was a horrible mistake. I'm anti-war.
 
 Now, are you going to just sit there and simply claim that these are contrary views of a self deluded mind, or are you going to actually try to support that claim?
jyoshu

I think our troops are, for the most part, doing their duty as best they can in a horrible situation. I wish them the best and would like them home soon and safely. I'm pro-troops.
 
 I think the Iraq war was a horrible mistake. I'm anti-war.
 
 Now, are you going to just sit there and simply claim that these are contrary views of a self deluded mind, or are you going to actually try to support that claim?

 
 Just in terms of their morale alone, you are certainly anti-troops. Supporting a constant one-sided media drumbeat that mostly just questions what they're doing, as well as only reporting the bad news of their work and rarely ever their successes, yeah you're anti-troops. There's no way around it. Not to mention the condescending insult (even if unintentional) to them when you make assertions like "oh, they're just doing their duty", as if they don't really think through the issue of the war too or are incapable of it. Apparently it has never occured to you that the reason many are willingly there (yes, willingly) is that they HAVE thought through it and feel it is the right thing to do? 
 
 Probably not. Just grunts doing their duty, after all, huh? emoticon_rolleyes
Kronus

Just in terms of their morale alone, you are certainly anti-troops. 

 Any action can have positive and negative consequences. You've chosen to look at one minor aspect of being anti-war, the fact that it could possibly have some impact on morale, and pretend that outweighs every other consideration. If the troops have to suffer a dip in morale now so that they won't have to die in some hellhole for no good reason later, then that's the way it has to be. It would be great if we could tell the administration that their war policies are stupid and have it have no impact on troop morale, but if we can't we can't. Getting Bush to stop spending our soldiers lives for his own political gain is the important thing, and if we have to hurt their feelings briefly to save their lives than so be it.
 
 

 Supporting a constant one-sided media drumbeat that mostly just questions what they're doing, as well as only reporting the bad news of their work and rarely ever their successes, yeah you're anti-troops.

 And now you're just making stuff up. I've never done any of that. You're taking every person who ever said anything against the war and glomming them together into one big composite "liberal", and assigning that composite whichever traits you like least from the members you used to construct it. Like it or not, lots of people who are against the war actually think differently, and don't all have the same motivations.
 
 

 Not to mention the condescending insult (even if unintentional) to them when you make assertions like "oh, they're just doing their duty", 

 
 When a conservative says it, it's patriotism; when a liberal says it, it's condescending? I see.
